1.question: In the heart
1.A: The right atrium is the most posterior chamber
1.B: The crista terminalis separates the right atrium from its appendage
1.C: The left ventricle is characterised by a muscular conus (or infundibulum) and trabeculae carnae
1.D: The left atrium receives two pulmonary veins
1.E: The left ventricle is the most anterior chamber

2.question: Regarding the coronary arteries
2.A: The right coronary artery arises from the right posterior aortic sinus
2.B: The sinoatrial node is usually supplied by the right coronary artery
2.C: Approximately 90% of individuals show right coronary artery dominance
2.D: The circumflex artery has several diagonal branches
2.E: The left anterior descending artery runs in the atrioventricular groove

3.question: Regarding axial CT scan of the mediastinum
3.A: Left atrium is anterior to the right atrium
3.B: Superior vena cava lies to the left of the ascending aorta
3.C: Oesophagus is posteromedial to the arch of the aorta
3.D: Thoracic duct lies anterior to the oesophagus
3.E: The left superior pulmonary vein is separated from the left lower lobe pulmonary artery by the bronchus

4.question: In the hilum
4.A: Bronchial arteries lie superior to the pulmonary arteries
4.B: Left pulmonary artery lies below the left main bronchus
4.C: Right pulmonary artery lies anterior to the right main bronchus
4.D: Maximum diameter of the normal descending branch of the right pulmonary artery is 12 mm in males
4.E: Intrapulmonary lymphatics drain directly to the bronchopulmonary nodes

5.question: Regarding the normal chest
5.A: The fissures are seen as a relatively avascular zone on a standard CT thorax
5.B: The azygous lobe fissure is seen in 5-10% of normal population
5.C: The superior accessory fissure separates the apical segment from the anterior and posterior segments of the upper lobe
5.D: The inferior accessory fissure separates the medial from the other segments in the right lower lobe
5.E: The inferior pulmonary ligament represents pleural reflections from the mediastinum which hang down from the hila.

6.question: In the PA radiograph of the chest
6.A: The left hilum lies lower than the right
6.B: The upper lobe pulmonary veins lie medial to the arteries
6.C: The lateral basal segment of the right lower lobe overlies the postero-basal segment
6.D: Apical segment of the right lower lobe overlies part of the posterior segment of the upper lobe
6.E: The posterior junctional line extends more superior than the anterior junctional line

7.question: Regarding the orbit
7.A: The nasolacrimal duct drains into the middle meatus
7.B: The optic nerve traverses the superior orbital fissure
7.C: The oculomotor nerve supplies the inferior oblique muscle
7.D: The ophthalmic artery arises from the internal carotid artery
7.E: The superior rectus muscle is inferior to the levator palpabrae superioris

8.question: In the skull
8.A: The optic foramina are medial to the anterior clinoid process
8.B: The tuberculum sellae is superior to the anterior clinoid process
8.C: The anterior clinoid process is lateral to the ipsilateral posterior clinoid process
8.D: The medial clinoid process is a constant feature in the normal population
8.E: The frontal sinus may extend into the orbital plate of the frontal bone

9.question: Regarding the pituitary gland
9.A: The pituitary gland is superior to the suprasellar cistern
9.B: The thickness of the infundibulum normally exceeds the diameter of basilar artery
9.C: The posterior pituitary usually returns a high signal on T1-weighted images
9.D: Maldescended pituitary tissue may be found as a soft tissue mass expanding the infundibulum
9.E: The pituitary gland is usually of a constant size in adult

10.question: In the temporomandibular joint
10.A: An articular disc divides the joint cavity into anterior and posterior compartments
10.B: The lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted partly into the articular disc
10.C: The capsule is attached inferiorly to the coronoid process of mandible
10.E: Less stable in the open position

11.question: The cavernous sinus
11.B: Drains into the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses
11.C: Contains the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve
11.D: Lies lateral to the sphenoid sinus and pituitary fossa

12.question: Regarding the ear
12.A: The second part of the facial canal lies inferior to the lateral semi-circular canal
12.B: The carotid canal lies in the anterior wall of the middle ear
12.C: The stapes inserts into the round window
12.D: The mastoid antrum lies posterior to the middle ear
12.E: Porus acousticus divides the internal auditory meatus (IAM) into upper and lower compartments

13.question: Regarding the pharynx and related spaces
13.A: Pterygomaxillary fissure connects the pterygopalatine fossa with the infratemporal fossa
13.B: The epiglottis marks the inferior limit of the laryngopharynx
13.C: The infratemporal space is limited medially by the lateral pterygoid plate
13.D: On axial imaging of the nasopharynx, the fossae of Rosenmüller are posterior to the torus tubarius
13.E: On CT scan, the parapharyngeal space is seen as fat density anteromedial to the styloid process

14.question: Regarding the thyroid and parathyroid glands
14.A: The pyramidal lobe extends superiorly from the left lobe
14.B: The right lobe is usually larger and vascular than the left lobe
14.C: The thyroid gland appears relatively homogenous in echotexture and hyperechoic than the sternocleidomastoid muscle on ultrasound
14.D: 99mTc pertechnetate imaging provides functional data on the thyroid gland
14.E: The thyroid derives its blood supply from the external and internal carotid arteries

15.question: Regarding the spinal cord
15.A: It extends in the adult from the foramen magnum to the L1/L2 level
15.B: The lumbar segments correspond to the level of the lumbar vertebrae
15.C: On plain CT, the low-density epidural fat outlines the thecal sac
15.D: The first to seventh cervical spinal nerves exit below the pedicle of the corresponding vertebrae
15.E: The anterior horns of the spinal cord contain the cell bodies of the motor neurons

16.question: Regarding the oesophagus
16.A: Commences at the cricopharyngeal muscle at C4
16.B: Pierces the diaphragm with the right phrenic nerve
16.C: Has striated muscle in the wall of its upper third, and smooth muscle in the wall more distally
16.D: Is retroperitoneal in its intra-abdominal portion
16.E: Receives part of its blood supply from the thyrocervical trunk

17.question: Regarding the duodenum
17.A: The first part lies anterior to the gastroduodenal artery
17.B: The first part lies posterior to the gallbladder and the quadrate lobe of the liver
17.C: The second part lies anterior to the left kidney
17.D: The third part lies anterior to the superior mesenteric vessels
17.E: The para duodenal fossa lies to the left of the fourth part of the duodenum

18.question: Regarding the liver
18.A: The caudate lobe separates the porta hepatis from the inferior vena cava
18.B: Segment V is the anterior inferior segment of the liver
18.C: Venous drainage of the quadrate lobe is usually distinct from the rest of the liver, direct to the inferior vena cava rather than into the hepatic veins
18.D: The ligamentum venosum is the remnant of the left umbilical vein
18.E: The liver is hyperintense to spleen on T1- weighted MRI images

19.question: Regarding the spleen
19.B: Its posterior aspect is related to the stomach
19.C: The tail of pancreas abuts against the hilum
19.D: The left kidney is related to its medial aspect
19.E: The main blood supply is from the superior mesenteric artery

20.question: The common bile duct
20.A: Lies to the right of the gastroduodenal artery
20.B: Lies posterolateral to the portal vein
20.C: Drains into the 2nd part of duodenum
20.D: Has a maximum diameter of 11mm on ultrasonography
20.E: Has a separate opening from the pancreatic duct in 40% of patient

21.question: Regarding peritoneal spaces
21.A: The right subphrenic space extends from the right coronary ligament postero-inferiorly to the falciform ligament medially
21.B: In the supine position the hepatorenal space (Morrison’s pouch) is more dependant than the right paracolic gutter
21.C: The lesser sac is posterior to the pancreas
21.D: Fluid collections in the pelvis that spread to the left subphrenic space, generally involve the lesser sac
21.E: Subphrenic collections are more common on the left than the right

22.question: Regarding the ovaries
22.A: Venous drainage of the right ovary is to the right renal vein
22.C: Lie on posterior surface of broad ligament
22.D: On T2-weighted images, the ovarian stroma is isointense to fat
22.E: Prior to ovulation follicles measure approximately 18-24mm

23.question: The left kidney
23.A: Has the renal pelvis lying posterior to the artery
23.C: Lies in the anterior pararenal space
23.D: Has a duplex collecting system in 10% of patients
23.E: Has a renal cortex which is more echogenic than the liver on ultrasonography

24.question: Regarding the urinary tract
24.A: The accessory renal arteries arise from the lumbar arteries in the majority
24.B: In complete ureteral duplication, the ureter serving the upper moiety inserts inferior to the lower moiety
24.C: The lymphatic drainage of the urinary bladder drains into the internal iliac nodes
24.D: The trigone of the urinary bladder has coarse trabeculated muscle fibres
24.E: On plain radiograph, the kidney size is approximately three and a half lumbar vertebrae

25.question: Regarding the humerus
25.A: The short head of the biceps runs in between the lesser and greater tuberosities.
25.B: The deltoid tuberosity is on the lateral aspect of the mid-shaft
25.C: Trochlea articulates with the radial head
25.D: The secondary ossification centre of the greater tuberosity appears at one year
25.E: The anterior humeral line bisects the capitulum on the lateral radiograph

26.question: Regarding the shoulder
26.A: Glenohumeral ligament strengthens the anterior capsule of the shoulder joint
26.B: The subacromial bursa communicates with the shoulder joint
26.C: The teres major is part of the rotator cuff muscle
26.D: The tendon of the long head of bicep is seen as a filling defect in arthrography
26.E: The greater tuberosity is best seen on the PA view with internal rotation

27.question: Axillary artery
27.A: Begins at the medial border of the first rib
27.B: Is divided into three parts by pectoralis major muscle
27.C: Gives off the anterior circumflex humeral artery
27.D: Ends at the upper border of the teres major muscle
27.E: Gives off the lateral thoracic artery

28.question: In the knee joint
28.A: The articular surface is formed by femur, tibia, patella and fibula
28.B: The suprapatellar bursa lies between biceps femoris muscle and femur
28.C: The popliteus tendon sheath is related to the posterior horn of the medial meniscus
28.D: The posterior cruciate ligament inserts into the lateral surface of the medial femoral condyle
28.E: The skyline view demonstrates the intercondylar fossa

29.question: In the hip joint
29.A: The capsule is attached to the intertrochanteric crest posteriorly
29.B: The centre of the acetabulum is a non-articular area
29.C: For an AP radiograph, the leg is externally rotated
29.D: The normal acetabular angle is 45 degrees
29.E: The head appears hyperechoic in infant on ultrasound

30.question: Regarding arterial supply of the lower limb
30.A: The distal third of the superficial femoral artery passes in the adductor canal
30.B: The posterior tibial artery continues as the dorsalis pedis artery
30.C: The peroneal artery is lateral to the posterior tibial artery on AP view of angiogram
30.D: Medial circumflex artery branches from superficial femoral artery
30.E: The Valsalva manoeuvre slows down the arterial blood flow
